name: Zilong Wang
title: Research Scientist at Google DeepMind
about: Zilong Wang is a final-year Ph.D. student at UC San Diego, advised by Prof. Jingbo Shang. He specializes in natural language reasoning and multimodal data mining, with expertise in post-training and distilling language models to enhance reasoning and planning capabilities. His work also focuses on evaluating the reliability and robustness of LLMs in safety-critical contexts and integrating multimodal features to address tasks involving tables, images, and web pages. At Google, Zilong developed Speculative RAG, an RAG framework that achieves state-of-the-art performance both in accuracy and efficiency. This method employs a map-reduce framework, where smaller specialist LMs generate draft responses, which are then verified and refined by a larger generalist LM. Zilong also created the Chain-of-Table agent framework for solving tabular understanding tasks. This system allows LLMs to outline their reasoning step-by-step, iteratively updating a table to reflect the reasoning process. By segmenting tables into manageable parts, Chain-of-Table enhances the depth of table analysis. Additionally, Zilong developed an LLM debugging agent (LDB) to improve coding capabilities. The agent leverages runtime execution data to iteratively refine LLM-generated programs, achieving state-of-the-art performance on coding benchmarks such as HumanEval and MBPP. Earlier in his research, Zilong focused on Document AI, proposing LayoutReader, a multimodal model for detecting reading order in visually-rich documents. He has extended this experience to current LLM systems, introducing OfficeBench, a new agent benchmark for office automation tasks. Zilong has completed research internships at Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and Adobe, and his work has been published in top venues such as ICLR, ACL, EMNLP, and KDD.

name: Verena Rieser
title: Researcher at Google DeepMind + hon. Professor + Co-founder
about: I am a Senior Staff Research Scientist at Google DeepMind, where I lead an interdisciplinary team of highly talented researchers. My team is called "VOICES-of-all in alignment" reflecting our mission to align frontier models to pluralistic values. We sit under Safety & Alignment within GenAI. I am also honorary professor at Heriot-Watt University in Edinburgh and I have co-founded the Conversational AI company ALANA. I have researched and developed Conversational AI and Natural Language Generation systems for over 20 years. My research was awarded with a Royal Society/ Leverhulme Trust Senior Research fellowship in recognition of my work in developing multimodal conversational systems. Before joining DeepMind, I spent 11 years building a successful research group at Heriot-Watt University. My team inter alia won 3rd prize in the Amazon Alexa challenge twice in a row, organised the End-to-End NLG shared task which set a new research agenda for neural language generation, and co-led the evaluation of the BLOOM large language model. I was promoted to full professor in 2017 after only 5 years as faculty. I gained my PhD in 2009 from Saarland University in Germany on Reinforcement Learning for Spoken Dialogue Systems. I hold a MSc from the University of Edinburgh, where I also spent time as a postdoctoral researcher working on statistical language generation and briefly on climate change mitigation. I spend my UG close to home at the University of Regensburg, where I enjoyed a multi-disciplinary education in Information Science, Linguistics, Literature and Statistics.
source_query: Staff Research Scientist at Google DeepMind

name: Michael J.
title: AI Research Scientist @Anthropic | Former Senior ML Engineer @IBM | 20+ yrs in NLP, LLM Alignment, Speech & Applied AI
about: I am an AI research scientist with over 20 years of cross-disciplinary R&D experience in speech recognition, natural language processing (NLP), and large-scale language models (LLMs). I began my career at Peking University with a degree in Information Science. I then pursued a Master's degree in Computer Science at the University of Southern California (USC), focusing on speech recognition and statistical machine learning. I also worked on early speech modeling projects at SRI International, participating in the development of speech recognition prototypes for human-computer interaction systems. I joined IBM's New York Lab in 2006 and have held positions as a data mining engineer, machine learning engineer, and research engineer, focusing on applying NLP and ML systems to industry-wide scenarios such as intelligent customer service, semantic search, and financial risk management. During this time, I led multiple end-to-end AI projects, becoming proficient in model development and deployment using platforms such as TensorFlow, PyTorch, and Spark. I also facilitated the patenting and transformation of numerous research findings into enterprise solutions. Since 2021, I have joined Anthropic, where I have been involved in the design of key modules for large-scale language models (the Claude series), focusing on alignment, security, and conversational capabilities, particularly within subsystems such as RLHF, Constitutional AI, and long-context understanding. I built an experimental framework for the RLHF reward model, designed a multi-dimensional user preference scoring system, and assisted enterprise clients (in finance, law, education, and other sectors) with private model deployment and fine-tuning. During this work, I collaborated closely with multiple teams, including product, security, and legal, to ensure model compliance, security, and controllability. I also actively participated in research initiatives on AI ethics and system security, publishing relevant results at top international conferences such as NeurIPS and ICLR, and was invited to present at the Stanford AI Symposium. I believe that AI is not only an engineering challenge but also a social responsibility. The boundaries of technology must be stretched in tandem with human values. I welcome discussions and collaborations with you.

name: Ceslee Montgomery

about: As a Machine Learning Research Engineer, I am broadly interested in machine learning, natural language processing, and computer vision, with recent forays into multimodal (image + text) learning. Current directions include controllable and image-conditioned text generation and retrieval, text-conditioned image synthesis/editing, and improving model robustness with model-generated synthetic data augmentation. Prior directions includes integrating language, vision, and action for Embodied AI agents on the Vision-Language Navigation task. Over the last several years, as a Data Scientist with a social science background, I’ve influenced software product development through quantitative user insights and rapid prototyping of human-centered machine learning products. To optimize product impact, I’ve effectively leveraged quantitative and qualitative UX research, web behavior analytics, and A/B testing to increase key product performance metrics. I’m especially passionate about creating new and innovative ML-powered products grounded in user research. I’ve created novel proof of concepts for recommendation systems in fashion and education (end-to-end). *Keywords* Multimodal ML and its applications to: Open-Domain Retrieval, Text Generation, Image Synthesis Generation, Fashion/Retail, AI Content Creation, AR/VR. Work includes: Transformers, Transfer Learning/Vision and Language Pretraining, Model Quantification/Dataset Augmentation, A/B Experimentation, Quant UX/Analytics.

name: Shixiang Shane Gu

about: I am a Research Scientist at Google Brain, where I mainly work on problems in deep learning, reinforcement learning, robotics, and probabilistic machine learning. My recent research focuses on sample-efficient RL methods that could scale to solve difficult continuous control problems in the real-world, which have been covered by Google Research Blogpost and MIT Technology Review. I completed PhD in Machine Learning at the University of Cambridge and the Max Planck Institute for Intelligent Systems in Tübingen, where I was co-supervised by Richard E. Turner, Zoubin Ghahramani, and Bernhard Schölkopf. During my PhD, I also collaborated closely with Sergey Levine at UC Berkeley/Google Brain and Timothy Lillicrap at DeepMind. I hold my B.ASc. in Engineering Science from the University of Toronto, where I did my thesis with Geoffrey Hinton in distributed training of neural networks using evolutionary algorithms. I also had great fun time working with Steve Mann, developing real-time HDR capture for wearable cameras/displays. I interned at Google Brain hosted by Ilya Sutskever and Vincent Vanhoucke. I also volunteered as a Lab Scientist at Creative Destruction Lab, one of the leading tech-startup incubators in Canada. My PhD was funded by Cambridge-Tübingen PhD Fellowship, NSERC and Google Focused Research Award. I am a Japan-born Chinese Canadian, and I speak, read, and write in three languages. Having lived in Japan, China, Canada, the US, the UK, and Germany, I go under multiple names: Shane Gu, Shixiang Gu, 顾世翔, 顧世翔(ぐう せいしょう). My Chinese name means “world” (世) and “flying” (翔), and thus I “flew around the world”.

title: Senior Staff Research Scientist at Google
about: Donald Metzler is a Senior Staff Research Scientist at Google Inc. Prior to that, he was a Research Assistant Professor at the University of Southern California (USC) and a Senior Research Scientist at Yahoo!. He is a Distinguished Member of the ACM and the recipient of multiple Test of Time and Best Paper awards. He has served as the Program Chair of the WSDM, ICTIR, and OAIR conferences and sat on the editorial boards of all the major journals in his field. He has published over 100 research papers, has been awarded 10 patents, and is a co-author of “Search Engines: Information Retrieval in Practice”. He currently leads a research group focused on a variety of problems related to large language modeling foundations, generative information retrieval, trust and safety, information quality, factuality, and efficiency. For more information, see: * Web site: https://metzlerd.github.io/ * Google Scholar: https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=bmXpOd8AAAAJ * CV: https://metzlerd.github.io/files/metzler-cv.pdf
source_query: Staff Research Scientist at Google DeepMind

name: Lora Aroyo

location: New York, New York, United States
about: As a research scientist at Google, I have over six years of experience in developing and applying AI data quality metrics, human computation plurarity methods, and safety of generative AI techniques. My mission is to ensure that AI systems are reliable, trustworthy, and beneficial for users and society. I have a strong background in crowdsourcing and human computation, human-computer interaction, user-centric data science, and augmenting intelligence with humans in the loop. I leveraged these skills to design and evaluate recommender systems, user and context modeling, semantic web, e-learning, e-culture, and interactive TV applications. I also have expertise in intelligent educational systems, where I apply my PhD in agent-based information management to create adaptive and personalized learning environments.

name: Heiga Zen
title: Principal Scientist (Director) & Tokyo Site Lead, Google DeepMind; ISCA/IEEE Fellow
about: Dr. Heiga ZEN received the A.E. degree from the Suzuka National College of Technology, Suzuka, Japan, in 1999, and the B.E., M.E., and Ph.D. degrees from the Nagoya Institute of Technology, Nagoya, Japan, in 2001, 2003, and 2006, respectively. From June 2004 to May 2005, he was an intern/co-op researcher at the IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, U.S.A. From April 2006 to June 2008, he was a Research Associate at the Nagoya Institute of Technology. From July 2008 to July 2011, he was a Research Engineer at the Toshiba Research Europe Cambridge Research Laboratory, Cambridge, U.K. From July 2008 to November 2018, he was a Research Scientist at Google UK, London, U.K. From December 2018 to April 2023, he was a Research Scientist at Google Brain, Tokyo, Japan. Presently, he is a Principal Research Scientist at Google DeepMind, Tokyo, Japan. His research interests include speech processing and machine learning. Dr. Zen was awarded a 2006 ASJ Awaya Award, a 2008 ASJ Itakura Award, a 2008 TAF TELECOM System Technology Award, a 2008 IEICE Information and Systems Society Best Paper Award, a 2009 IPSJ Yamashita SIG Research Award, and a 2013 IPSJ Kiyasu Special Industrial Achievement Award. He is a member of the IEEE and ISCA, and was a member of the IEEE Speech and Language Processing Technical Committee (SLTC) between 2012 and 2014. He was also an Associate Editor of IEEE/ACM Transactions on Audio, Speech, and Language Processing between 2017 and 2020. He was elected as a fellow of ISCA in 2022. Specialties: Speech synthesis

name: Nikita Saxena

For her thesis, Nikita worked at Mila Quebec AI Institute under the supervision of Professor Yoshua Bengio, alongside Moksh Jain and Alex Hernandez Garcia, where she developed GFlowNets for scientific discovery. In the past, she has also had the opportunity of leading one of the early AI initiatives at Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) in 2020. Nikita is a recipient of the DAAD-WISE, Charpak Lab, and MITACS Globalink scholarships. She is committed to supporting the research community and currently serves on the Women in Machine Learning (WiML) Board.

name: Francis Grimes
title: AI & Healthcare Leader | AI-driven Precision Medicine | Medical Imaging & Drug Discovery
about: Technology is transforming the healthcare industry, and I have always been fascinated by how artificial intelligence empowers precision medicine. From early research in AI-driven medical imaging to exploring its role in accelerating drug discovery, I firmly believe that the combination of data and technology can lead to more precise and efficient healthcare solutions. I enjoy thinking about how AI can truly integrate into the healthcare system, not only improving diagnostic accuracy but also supporting doctors in making better decisions, ultimately making healthcare more personalized and accessible. Beyond my passion for technology, I focus on the connection between people and innovation. Healthcare is fundamentally about helping people, and AI’s value lies not in replacing doctors but in becoming a powerful assistant to them. I enjoy engaging with doctors, researchers, and industry leaders, understanding their challenges, and exploring how technology can create meaningful impact. If you are also interested in AI-driven precision medicine, medical imaging analysis, or healthcare innovation, I’d love to connect and discuss how we can drive the future of healthcare together.

name: Been Kim
title:
Senior Staff Research Scientist at Google DeepMind

[[I come here once in a blue moon. I tried to review 1000 requests that I've neglected for the last X years, but failed after two pages. Sorry it's not you, it's me]]
about: [I don't respond to LinkedIn msgs/invitations. For my latest publications, please visit beenkim.github.io/] My focus: ICLR keynote 2022 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ub45cGEcTB0&t=6s Blog: https://medium.com/@beenkim/beyond-interpretability-4bf03bbd9394 google scholar: https://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&user=aGXkhcwAAAAJ I am interested in helping humans to communicate with complex machine learning models: not only by building tools (and tools to criticize them), but also studying their nature, compared to humans. Quanta magazine (written by John Pavlus, https://www.quantamagazine.org/been-kim-is-building-a-translator-for-artificial-intelligence-20190110/) is a great description of what I do and why. I believe the language that humans and machines communicate must be human-centered--higher-level, human-friendly concepts--so that it can make sense to everyone , regardless of how much they know about ML. I gave keynote at ICLR 2022, ECML 2020 and at the G20 meeting in Argentina in 2018. One of my work TCAV received UNESCO Netexplo award, was featured at Google I/O 19' and in Brian Christian's book on The Alignment Problem. Stuff I help with: Senior Program Chair at ICLR 2023 Workshop Chair at ICLR 2019 Senior Area chair/Area chair/Senior program committee NeurIPS 2017-now, ICML 2019-now, ICLR 2020-now, AISTATS 2020-now Steering committee and area chair at IEEE Conference on Secure and Trustworthy Machine Learning Steering committee and area chair at FAccT conference Former executive board member and VP of Women in Machine Learning. Co-organizer of multi-year workshops of Human interpretability in ML (WHI) at ICML 2020 2018 2017 2016 , and NIPS 2016 Worshop on Interpretable Machine Learning for Complex Systems.

name: Tim Rocktäschel

about: I am a Director / Principal Scientist and the Open-Endedness Team Lead at Google DeepMind. I am also a Professor of Artificial Intelligence at the Centre for Artificial Intelligence in the Department of Computer Science at University College London (UCL) where I am PI of the UCL Deciding, Acting, and Reasoning with Knowledge (DARK) Lab, as well as a Fellow of the European Laboratory for Learning and Intelligent Systems (ELLIS). Before, I was managing the Reinforcement Learning Team at Meta AI (FAIR) London. I was a Postdoctoral Researcher in Reinforcement Learning at the Whiteson Research Lab at the University of Oxford, a Junior Research Fellow in Computer Science at Jesus College, and a Stipendiary Lecturer in Computer Science at Hertford College. I obtained my Ph.D. from UCL under the supervision of Sebastian Riedel, where I was awarded a Microsoft Research Ph.D. Scholarship in 2013 and a Google Ph.D. Fellowship in 2017. My work focuses on Artificial General Intelligence, Open-Endedness, and Self-Improvement, and it has received Best Paper Awards at ICML.

name: Claudio Fantacci
title: Staff Research Engineer @ Google DeepMind
about: I'm an engineer and a developer with knowledge sharing and problem solving attitudes. I have 6 years experience in recursive Bayesian filtering and software engineering with proven publication track record, including R&D collaboration with Selex ES (Finmeccanica) and a Ph.D. in computer science and automation engineering from University of Florence (Italy). I was recipient of the 2014 Australia Award Endeavour Research Fellowship (granted by the Australian Government, Department of Education) under which I have been an R&D collaborator at the Advanced Signal Processing Group of Curtin University of Technology (Perth, Australia). From January 2016, I'm a post-doc at the Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (Genoa, Italy) in the iCub Facility, Humanoid Sensing and Perception, for studying, researching and developing new augmented reality-based visual tracking software for visual servoing tasks for the humanoid robotic platform iCub. I actively contribute to the development of the free and open source software of the Robotology community (https://github.com/robotology) wherein I'm the maintainer of two libraries (https://github.com/robotology/bayes-filters-lib and https://github.com/robotology/superimpose-mesh-lib) and three iCub applications (https://github.com/robotology/visual-tracking-control). I also contribute to and develop other open source project during my research activities, like OpenCV, GLFW and glew. Main research interests: recursive Bayesian filtering, estimation and tracking (Kalman and Particle filters), visual tracking, augmented-reality, multi-object multi-sensor tracking using classic and Random Finite Set approach (PHD, CPHD, Labeled Multi-Bernoulli filters), distributed information fusion. Specialities: C/C++, MATLAB/Simulink, Git, CMake, OpenCV, OpenGL, Python, Java.

title: Applied Scientist
about: Expert in Digital Signal Processing and Machine learning, specifically in audio field. Passion and experience in leading technical teams and developing new technology roadmaps. Researched and developed many audio algorithms such has Acoustic Echo Cancellation, Adaptive Beamforming, Wind Noise, Noise suppression, Direction of Arrival estimation and tracking, Ultrasonics, acoustic modeling, playback processing, and various audio detection algorithms using a fusion of traditional DSP and Deep Learning techniques. Highly experienced in creating algorithm systems with an emphasis on productization. Expert in object oriented programming, real-time audio systems, and audio hardware validation and bring-up. Proven track record of shipping out millions of audio products across many product verticals.

name: Jonathan Reiber
title: Scenario and Strategic Planning at OpenAI
about: I write about security and culture and help organizations to build resilience and plan for risk. Currently, I research issues related to geopolitics and international security at OpenAI. Earlier in my career I was an executive at a cybersecurity company, held a senior fellowship at Berkeley's Center for Long-Term Cybersecurity, and spent seven years in the Obama administration as a speechwriter and strategist in the Defense Department. I often speak publicly about security and technology and extremism, and my written commentary has appeared in TIME Magazine, Foreign Policy, Lawfare, The Atlantic Monthly, Fortune Magazine, and Literary Hub, among others. I published a monograph, "A Public, Private War", about public-private cooperation for conflict in the digital age, the findings of which were adopted into national law. I love to trail run and be outside. You can find a small selection of my writing and work at www.jonathanreiber.com.

name: Joost Huizinga
title: Research Scientist at OpenAI
about: While my interests are broad, my current focus has been on tackling sparse and deceptive problems in the field of reinforcement learning, which has resulted in making substantial progress on the popular exploration benchmarks of Montezuma's Revenge and Pitfall. During my PhD, my research has focused on the role of structural organization in artificial neural networks, and it has demonstrated both how different forms of structural organization, like modularity, regularity, and hierarchy can improve the performance and adaptability of neural networks, as well as explored techniques on how to autonomously create neural networks that exhibit these properties with the help of evolutionary processes.

My primary goal is to simultaneously work toward AGI while developing domain-specific medical AI systems that will improve outcomes and quality of life for countless individuals. My primary interests are neurosurgery, brain-computer interface, and regenerative medicine.

name: Morgan Griffiths
title: Research Engineer
about: I have always been fascinated by games. Whether it was programming robots in RoboWars, exploring RPG dungeons or making up my own outdoors. While I often found rules arbitrary and annoying, i realized that games are fun and challenging because of their rules. The simplicity of the rules of a game, speak to me about how well the game is designed. Starting college at 15, i studied Russian (due to my Russian chess trainers) and functional linguistics. Linguistics teaches us about how we think, how language is a tool that we use to communicate and analyze the world around us. But it is also a box, with rules and constraints that forces you to think in certain ways. Just like how traveling opens your eyes to different modes of living, new languages open your mind up to different modes of thinking. And are better or worse at expressing different concepts. The beauty of deep strategic play in chess continues to remind me that optimal solutions are often surprising, subtle and can even appear to be going backward. The value of starting from what is known and working systematically to uncover the truth of the position. How the rules of a game dictate how the game should be played, something that isn't taken into account often enough in our governmental and political spheres. 11 years as a poker professional opened my eyes to the probabilistic nature of the universe. The fallacy of looking back on history at events as if they were certain. The importance of mixed strategies and how the frequency of an action can determine whether or not that action is correct. I've also learned a lot about how to consistently perform well as a competitor. How diet, exercise, meditation and routine can create the foundation for performing at a high level. When to accept that circumstances are not right for excelling. Knowing when to quit is often the more important skill. I went into programming and ML because i fear that humanity is ill suited to being good stewards of this planet and is on the path to self extinction. If we want our civilization to extend for millions of years, we must design systems that take the long tails of the future into account. With machine learning, we finally have the ability to create an intelligence outside of ourselves that can augment our understanding and make up for our blind spots. Fundamentally if truly intelligent systems can be developed on our digital substrate vs our analog brains. It would be a more alien form of intelligence than even octopuses. National individual chess champion (2003)

name: José Carlos noma
title: AI Research Engineer/OpenAI
about: As an AI Research Engineer with a deep commitment to advancing artificial intelligence, I specialize in leveraging cutting-edge technology to address intricate real-world challenges. My lifelong fascination with computers has evolved into a profound expertise in solving complex problems, which has naturally led me to the field of AI research. I am dedicated to pushing the boundaries of scientific knowledge through the development and application of innovative algorithms. My experience encompasses a range of challenging projects, where I have focused on employing deep learning techniques to enhance system intelligence, thereby enabling more precise understanding and responses to human needs. In addition to my technical acumen, I possess a strong appreciation for the arts and am a firm advocate for integrating technological progress with humanistic principles. Looking forward, my goal is to continue exploring and advancing cutting-edge technologies, contributing to a future that is both intellectually robust and ethically sound. I am eager to collaborate in exploring the vast potential of AI technology to drive meaningful progress.

name: Antoine Dedieu
title: Senior Research Scientist at Google DeepMind
about: I am a Research Scientist at DeepMind. My current research interests are in building object-centric generative models from vision, and in solving the associated learning and inference problems. Prior to joining DeepMind, I worked 3.5 years as a Research Scientist then as a Senior Research Scientist at Vicarious (acquired by Alphabet) where I was building an AI layer for robots. My research there was combining probabilistic graphical models with cognitive science to build neuroscience-inspired generative models for vision which generalized from a limited number of training examples. Prior to joining Vicarious, I graduated from MIT Operations Research Center Master of Science, where I was advised by Prof. Rahul Mazumder. My thesis lied at the intersection of Machine Learning, Optimization and Statistics, building new algorithms to compute interpretable estimators, and studying their statistical performance. Before MIT, I earned an MS in Applied Mathematics from Ecole Polytechnique.

about: 🔸=I have signed the 10% pledge to donate 10% of my income to effective charities. https://www.givingwhatwecan.org/pledge Well-targeted donations can do a shockingly large amount of good, I encourage other people to do it too! https://www.givewell.org/ Note: Please DO NOT message me on LinkedIn, I will not read it. Email me instead. I am not interested in new job opportunities or consultancy requests. My goal is to spend my career working on important problems and helping to make the world a better place. I think the development of human-level AI has the potential to be one of the most important things to happen this century, and the main focus of my research is on ensuring that this is a robustly good thing for the world. Currently, this looks like staring REALLY hard at transformers and trying to figure out how they work. I consider myself part of the Effective Altruism community, and this has been a significant influence on my career decisions. The world is FULL of important problems, and I've only had a chance to explore a small part of this, so if you think your work is helping to make the world a better place, I'd love to hear from you! I blog about these ideas and other things at neelnanda.io

about: I help envision and shape new products and services. Melding two decades of experience in strategy and design, I lead teams that harmonize radically different points of view and problem-solving approaches. Together, we turn ambiguity into clearly-framed choices, and distill options into compelling visualizations and practical next-steps. It takes both spreadsheets and great storytelling. By infusing the future state with detail and color, I make it easier for leaders to commit and help them inspire stakeholders to get on board. The result is product and service innovation that delights and delivers lasting value. Because the journey together is full of discovery and practical lessons, everyone feels bought in--and glad they joined in. When design, engineering, creativity, and strategy each make a contribution, something wonderful happens. name: Casey Meehan
title: Member of Technical Staff @ OpenAI
about: [ https://casey-meehan.github.io/ ] My research focuses on personal data privacy in machine learning from two angles: 1) understanding and quantifying how large models memorize their training data, which can lead to leaking individuals' sensitive information, and 2) taking an application-specific approach to offering provable privacy in different ML settings. My publications have addressed privacy in contemporary ML domains -- defining privacy for LLM embeddings as well as generatively reconstructing the training data of large vision models -- as well as more classical domains -- formalizing privacy for individual's sensitive location data or social network data.
